title: Ayers v. Freeman
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Gregory L.
      Ayers, M.D., Thomas L. Brown, M.D., Bill R. Chandler, Everette P. Fuller,
      M.D., and Reidville Investment Properties, LLC., Respondents,
				v.
				W. E. Freeman, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Roger L. Couch, Master-in-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-358
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed August 6,
  2007
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled October
  9, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Oscar W. Bannister, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				M. Kyle Thompson and Mason A. Goldsmith, both of Greenville, for
  Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  W.
  E. Freeman appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s acceptance of the accounting
  performed by Cordell Porter.Â  Freeman contends the master erred in: (1) appointing
  Porter because he was biased in favor of Respondents; (2) failing to give proper
  notice of when the accounting would take
  place, thereby depriving Freeman of an opportunity to submit additional
  information to Porter for the purposes of an accounting; (3) awarding damages based on a flawed accounting;
  (4) finding Freemanâ€™s commissions were limited to the funds actually received;
  and (5) allowing Respondents to amend their complaint. Â We affirm.Â   
FACTS
In late 1994, Gregory Ayers, Thomas L. Brown, Everette Fuller,
  Bill Chandler (collectively Respondents), and Freeman formed a general
  partnership called Reidville Investment Properties.Â  Reidville Investment
  Properties was succeeded by Reidville Investment Properties, LLC (Reidville),
  which engaged in the real estate development business.Â  Reidville sought to
  develop property into a residential subdivision known as Abner Creek Station
  (Abner Creek).Â  In order to develop Abner Creek, Reidville obtained a loan in
  excess of $1,000,000.Â  Each of the individual Respondents and Freeman were
  personally liable for the entire amount under the terms of the loan.Â   
Reidville selected Freeman as manager due to his background in
  accounting and business management.Â  Freeman was licensed by South Carolina as
  an accounting practitioner and held himself out to be an accounting and bookkeeping
  professional.Â  Freeman maintained all books and records of Reidville,
  controlled the outflow of money, balanced the checkbook, received the bank
  statements, and had the responsibility of all bookkeeping activities.Â  Reidvilleâ€™s
  operating agreement entitled Freeman to a ten percent commission from the sale
  of all lots in Abner Creek.
Abner Creek was not successful.Â  The sales of lots in Abner Creek arranged
  by Freeman were based upon small cash payments with mortgages for the remainder
  of the purchase price. Â He subordinated these mortgages to those of the
  financing banks.Â  Freeman never collected the second mortgages owed to
  Reidville, and some of them ended up being uncollectible.Â  In 1998 and 1999,
  the other members of Reidville became concerned about Freemanâ€™s sparse
  reporting of the financial situation and repeatedly requested to be provided
  with a balance sheet, profit and loss statement, and other financial
  information.Â  Freeman provided very little of this information and resigned as
  manager in May 1999. Â 
Reidville then retained Cordell Porter to undertake the task of
  sorting and maintaining Reidvilleâ€™s books and records.Â  The records Porter received
  from Freeman were in disarray.Â  Many documents were missing and Porter
  discovered that many checks written on behalf of Reidville had no invoice or
  documentation justifying the expense.Â  Bank statements and cancelled checks
  were missing.Â  After reviewing the documentation Freeman had provided, Porter further
  discovered certain dividends from investments had been deposited into Freemanâ€™s
  personal accounts.Â  An additional bank account in Reidvilleâ€™s name, of which
  the other partners had no knowledge, was also discovered.Â  This account reflected
  numerous deposits and withdrawals with no substantiation as to where the funds
  came from or why the withdrawals were made.Â   
Additionally, Respondents were forced to personally pay loans and interest
  payments that were called because of Reidvilleâ€™s lack of funds.Â  Freeman did
  not contribute to these payments.Â  Also, Reidville sold a 225 acre tract of
  land, known as the Runion Tract, in order to avoid foreclosure.[1]
Respondents brought this action against Freeman, seeking inter alia, an accounting and actual and punitive damages for breach of his
  fiduciary duties to Reidville.Â  Freeman answered and counterclaimed for fees
  and expenses he claimed were due under the operating agreement as well as
  wages.Â  The matter was referred to a master by consent of the parties.Â   
Prior to the hearing, Respondents filed a motion and proposed
  amended complaint identical to the original complaint except for the addition
  of an equitable subrogation cause of action.Â  On the day of the hearing, the
  master denied the motion, but told the parties he would reconsider the motion
  at the end of the hearing.Â  At the end of the hearing, the master granted the
  motion to amend.Â  The master also indicated he was considering whether an
  accounting was necessary, given the work that had already been done to
  reconstruct the books.Â  Respondents suggested that if a further accounting was
  required, Porter should be the accountant due to his familiarity with the
  books.Â  The master asked both attorneys to submit letters concerning the
  necessity of having someone perform an accounting and to recommend an individual
  to perform the task.Â  Ultimately, the master found Freeman had breached his
  fiduciary duty and the individual Respondents were entitled to equitable
  subrogation against Freeman.Â  The master further ordered Porter to perform an
  accounting on behalf of the court.Â   
After Porter issued his final report, the master adopted the accounting
  in his order.Â  Freeman filed a rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion, claiming that he did
  not have the opportunity to participate in the accounting and seeking to
  present new evidence.Â  The master denied the motion, finding that Freeman knew
  the accounting by Porter was taking place, but failed to participate in it.Â 
  Further, he held Freeman sought to introduce materials which were not new and which
  had been available at the time of the hearing.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Accounting
Freeman contends the accounting was improper for the following
  reasons: (1) the appointment of Porter was improper because Porter was biased
  in favor of the Respondents; (2) Freeman was not given proper notice of the
  accounting thereby depriving him of his right to submit additional evidence; and
  (3) the master erred in awarding damages based on this flawed accounting.Â Â  We
  disagree.Â   
A.Â  Appointment of Porter
Freeman
  asserts the master erred in appointing Porter to perform the accounting because
  Porter had previously been used as a witness for the Respondents and was
  therefore biased in Respondentsâ€™ favor.Â  We disagree.
At
  the close of trial, the master noted that both sides had requested an
  accounting. Â He also expressed concern that retaining an accountant would be an
  added expense to the parties, and that he was considering using Porter in that
  capacity.  Counsel for Freeman stated he had no problem with the work
  Porter had done so far, but he did express reluctance to use him for the
  accounting since he had testified in favor of Reidville.   
The
  master then requested counsel to submit letters concerning the
  accounting.  Counsel for Reidville thereafter sent a letter to the court
  expressing a preference to have Porter perform the accounting.  Subsequently,
  counsel for Freeman submitted a letter agreeing that an accounting was needed;
  however, counsel neither objected to the use of Porter nor suggested anyone in
  the alternative. Â By order dated July 6, 2004, the master issued the final
  order with Porterâ€™s accounting attached thereto.  Counsel for Freeman
  filed a motion to alter or amend the order, but did not raise any issue
  regarding the appointment of Porter.
We
  hold that Freeman cannot now challenge the propriety of appointing Porter to
  perform the accounting.  Freeman never objected to the use of Porter and he
  failed to suggest an alternative accountant.  See Gambrell v.
    Gambrell, 295 S.C. 457, 460, 369 S.E.2d 662, 664 (Ct. App. 1988) (holding
  Wife could not complain of any alleged omission in the family courtâ€™s equitable
  division where the trial judge left it up to the parties to petition the court
  for a determination of the division scheme of certain assets and Wife failed to
  do this); cf. Hough v. Hough, 312 S.C. 344, 347, 440 S.E.2d 387,
  389 (Ct.App.1994) (finding litigant may not sit back and fail to offer evidence
  on a matter and then be heard to complain on that issue); Honea v. Honea,
  292 S.C. 456, 357 S.E.2d 191 (Ct.App.1987) (explaining the burden is on
  appellant to show the trial court committed reversible error and a party cannot
  sit back at trial without offering proof, then come to the appellate court
  complaining of the insufficiency of evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s
  findings).Â  Moreover, even if we were to construe Freemanâ€™s counselâ€™s statement
  at the close of trial as an objection to Porter performing the accounting, the
  master did not rule on this issue in his order. Because Freeman failed to raise
  this issue in his Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion, it is not preserved for our
  review.Â  Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526
  S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000) (â€œIf the losing party has raised an issue in the lower
  court, but the court fails to rule upon it, the party must file a motion to
  alter or amend the judgment in order to preserve the issue for appellate
  reviewâ€).
B.Â 
  Notice of accounting
Freeman
  also asserts he was not given proper notice of when the accounting would take
  place nor was he given an opportunity to submit additional information to
  Porter for the purposes of an accounting.Â  Because these arguments were not
  raised at the first opportunity, we find they are not preserved for our review.
On
  September 26, 2003, the master sent a letter to both parties advising them that
  Porter had been selected as the accountant.Â  Despite this notice, Freeman chose not to participate.Â  On
  May 4, 2004, the master adopted Porterâ€™s accounting; however, a final order was
  not signed until July 6, 2004.Â  Freeman lodged no objection to the accounting
  during this two-month period.Â  Because Freeman failed to raise any objections prior
  to the masterâ€™s issuance of a final order, the issues regarding notice are not
  preserved for our review.[2]Â  See In re Beard, 359 S.C.
  351, 361, 597 S.E.2d 835, 840 (Ct. App. 2004) (finding issue not raised prior
  to trial courtâ€™s final order was not preserved for review).
II.Â  Commissions 
Freeman
  contends the master erred in holding that the commissions due on the sale of
  the lots under the agreement were limited to the funds actually received by
  Reidville as opposed to the sales price of the lots sold.Â  Specifically, Freeman
  contends he is due commissions on the lots sold even where the money was not
  collected, and from the sale of the Runion Tract.Â  We disagree.
The agreement
  sets out the commission to be paid Freeman in the following terms:Â   

	(a) Property
  Development:Â  Development of the property shall be under the direction of
  William E. Freeman.Â  He will be paid a 10% commission on the sale of all 
	lots as a development and management fee.Â  This development and
  management agreement, separately written, shall run for an initial period of
  five (5) years with renewal to be by mutual consent.Â  

(Emphasis added).
Partnership
  agreements are construed pursuant to the rules of contract interpretation.[3]Â  See, Kuznik v. Bees Ferry Associates, 342 S.C. 579, 538 S.E.2d 15
  (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The cardinal rule of contract interpretation is to ascertain and
  give legal effect to the partiesâ€™ intentions as determined by the contract
  language. Â United Dominion Realty Trust, Inc. v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc.,
  307 S.C. 102, 105, 413 S.E.2d 866, 868 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  When a contract is unambiguous a court must construe
  its provisions according to the terms the parties used, as understood in their
  plain, ordinary, and popular sense. Â C.A.N. Enters., Inc. v. S.C. Health
    & Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 296 S.C. 373, 377, 373 S.E.2d 584, 586
  (1988).
As for the sale of the Runion tract, the partnership
  agreement unambiguously provided for commissions based on the sale of lots only.Â 
  The Runion Tract was a single, two hundred twenty-five acre tract of land,
  which had not been developed and only partially divided.Â  This sale was forced
  in order to avoid a foreclosure, and resulted in a loss to Reidville.Â  Additionally,
  the Runion tract was sold as a single parcel by Reidville, not subdivided and
  sold as part of the Abner Creek development.Â  Therefore, the sale of the Runion
  Tract does not fit the definition of a lot as contemplated in the partiesâ€™
  agreement.Â  Accordingly, the master did not err in failing to award Freeman a commission
  from the sale of the Runion Tract.Â  Â Â 
Freeman claims he
  is owed additional commissions on the dollar amounts of the sale, regardless of
  what was eventually collected by Reidville.Â  We disagree.Â  As the evidence
  showed, Freeman, by agreeing to allow purchasers to give subordinate second
  mortgages, collected very little money on the sale of many lots.Â  Freeman
  should not be allowed commissions on money never received by Reidville.Â  The
  agreement contemplated commissions based on the sale of lots, clearly envisioning
  commissions based on the receipt of money.Â  Accordingly, the master did not err
  in limiting Freemanâ€™s commissions to a percentage of money actually received.
III.Â  Amended Complaint
Finally,
  Freeman contends the master erred in granting the Respondentsâ€™ motion to amend
  their complaint to allow a claim for equitable subrogation.Â  We disagree.Â  
 
The
  motion to amend was made July 3, 2003, and the
  hearing was held July 17 and 18, 2003.Â  Â The amended complaint added a
  claim for equitable subrogation which related to the loan and interest payments
  Freeman failed to make beginning in 1999 and also to the balance of the loan
  which Respondents were forced to pay, even though Freeman was an equal
  guarantor.Â   
Rule
  15, SCRCP, provides the complaint may only be amended by leave of the court and
  â€œleave to amend shall be freely given when justice requires and does not
  prejudice any other party.â€ Â A motion to amend is within the sound discretion
  of the court, and the opposing party has the burden of establishing prejudice. Â Foggie
    v. CSX Transp., Inc., 315 S.C. 17, 22, 431 S.E.2d 587, 590 (1993).Â  The
  only time such an amendment should not be granted is when granting it would
  prejudice the other party, and the prejudice envisioned is the lack of notice
  an issue is going to be tried and a lack of opportunity to refute it.Â  Parker
    v. Spartanburg Sanitary Sewer Dist., 362 S.C. 276, 286, 607 S.E.2d 711, 716
  (Ct. App. 2005).Â   
By Freemanâ€™s own
  admission, he knew equitable subrogation would be an issue prior to trial; in
  fact he had been examined in prior depositions on this very issue.Â  Freeman
  also acknowledged he knew Respondents were pursuing the loan payments.Â  The
  master was advised Freeman had been asked about those payments at his
  deposition prior to the trial.Â  Freeman had the opportunity to question
  witnesses about the issue after the motion to amend had been filed.Â  The master
  stated at the beginning of the hearing that the issue would be revisited, thus
  clearly putting Freeman on notice the issue may be tried.Â  Accordingly, Freeman
  suffered no prejudice in allowing Respondents to amend their complaint, and the
  master did not abuse his discretion in allowing the amendment.Â   
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the masterâ€™s order is
  hereby
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., and CURETON,
  A.J., concur.

[1]Â  Reidville owned the 225 acre Runion Tract
  independent of the property being developed as Abner Creek.Â  The sale of the
  Runion Tract resulted in a $100,000 loss to Reidville.
[2] Â Due to our disposition of the primary issue in this
  matter, we need not address Freemanâ€™s argument that the master erred in
  awarding damages based on a flawed accounting.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993)
  (stating the appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution
  of a prior issue is dispositive).
[3] While Reidville was converted from a partnership to
  an LLC, the commissions were still governed by the former partnership
  agreement.Â

        Travis L.
          Allen, Petitioner

Appeal From Greenville County
John C. Few, Plea Judge
Â D. Garrison Hill, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-359
  Submitted June 29, 2007 â€“ Filed August 8,

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Deputy Chief Attorney Wanda H. Carter, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
          Attorney General Karen Ratigan, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from the partial
  grant and partial denial of his application for post-conviction relief (PCR).[1]
Because there is
  sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that petitioner did not
  knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, we grant
  certiorari on petitionerâ€™s Question I and proceed with a review of the direct
  appeal issue pursuant to Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60
  (1986).Â  
We
  find no merit to Allenâ€™s argument that the plea judge failed to advise Allen of
  his right to confront accusers.Â  The plea judge specifically informed Allen
  that by pleading guilty, he was giving up his right â€œto confront witnesses
  called by the State against [him].â€Â  Accordingly, Allenâ€™s conviction for murder
  is 
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., and
  HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
  

[1]Â  Allen argues his plea was not voluntarily made.Â  The
  PCR judge rejected this argument finding Allenâ€™s testimony was not credible.Â 
  Furthermore, the record from the guilty plea establishes that Allen entered a
  free, voluntary, and knowing plea.Â  Because there is evidence in the record to
  support the PCR judgeâ€™s decision, we deny certiorari on Allenâ€™s allegation his
  plea was involuntarily made.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109-10,
  525 S.E.2d 514, 517 (2000) (explaining that the existence of any evidence is
  sufficient to uphold the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling).

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDTIAL VALUE AND SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ronnie D. Robinson, Appellant,
				v.
				Anderson News Company, Employer, and The Hartford, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Jasper County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-362
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed August 28, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.


	
		
			
				Dennis Robert Toney, Jr., of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Stephen L. Brown, F. Drake Rogers, Russell G. Hines, all of Charleston, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case, Ronnie Robinson appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order.Â  Robinson contends the circuit court erred in finding he had reached maximum medical improvement (MMI) as of July 16, 2001, in finding he did not sustain a psychological overlay injury as a result of his physical injuries, and in failing to order additional medical care and treatment.Â  Robinson also argues it was improper for the circuit court to address the issue of whether he had sustained his burden of proving a period of temporary total disability (TTD) from February 11, 2001 to July 16, 2001.Â  Finally, Robinson contends the circuit court erred in considering facts and issues not in the record.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. [1]Â  
 

FACTS 
On July 9, 2000, Robinson was injured while unloading plastic containers from a truck owned by Respondent Anderson News Company. Â Â The containers were stacked in the back of a truck and fell onto Robinson striking him on the right side of his head, neck, and chest, knocking him to the ground.[2]Â  The next day, Robinson reported the incident to Respondent Anderson who sent him to Doctorâ€™s Care where he was seen by Dr. Richard Rhodes. Â Pursuant to a MRI performed in August 2000, Dr. Rhodes diagnosed Robinson with a herniated disc, returned him to work with the restriction that he not lift anything, and referred him to Dr. George Khoury, a neurologist.Â 
 
Dr. Khoury saw Robinson on September 7, 2000.Â  After reviewing the previous MRI, Dr. Khoury recommended Robinson â€œtry some conservative treatmentâ€ starting with anti-inflammatory medications and injections. Â Dr. Khoury referred Robinson to Trident Hospital where he received two cervical epidural steroid injections which, according to Robinson, did not help his pain.Â Â 
 
Robinson was next referred to Dr. Joseph Marzluff, a neurologist, who saw Robinson on November 8, 2000.Â Â  After reviewing the previous MRI, Dr. Marzluff opined that the MRI showed â€œdegenerative changes, but no significant disc herniation.â€Â  Dr. Marzluff suggested Robinson undergo physical therapy but stated, beyond that, he had â€œnothing specific to offerâ€ at that time and discharged him to return to work with the restriction that he refrain from lifting anything weighing over ten pounds.Â  Robinson then tried physical therapy, but returned to Dr. Marzluff on November 29, 2000.Â  Dr. Marzluff noted Robinson continued to be symptomatic of neck pain and planned to do a myelogram and post-myelogram CT with the possibility of â€œa discography following that with the thought that surgery might be beneficial if we can see some significant abnormalities.â€Â Â 
 
Robinson was next referred to Dr. Steven C. Poletti by Pat Botti, Robinsonâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation nurse case manager.Â  Based on his review of the MRI, Dr. Poletti diagnosed Robinson with â€œ[c]entral disc herniation, C3-4, with osteophyte/possible symptomatic disc degeneration at C5-6.â€Â Â Â  Dr. Poletti suggested the same treatment plan recommended by Dr. Marzluff.Â Â Â  Dr. Poletti gave Robinson an impairment rating â€œin the range of 10% if treated inoperativelyâ€ with permanent restrictions â€œof no heavy overhead lifting greater than 35 to 40 pounds, and no constant driving.â€ 
 
Dr. Poletti ordered a second MRI, which was taken on January 8, 2001.Â Â Â  Dr. Polettiâ€™s review of the second MRI revealed â€œC5-6 disc degeneration with posterior protrusion and modic end plate changes consistent with advanced degeneration.â€Â  Dr. Poletti suggested surgery and concluded if Robinson chose not to undergo surgery he would be at MMI and his impairment rating would be 10% but if Robinson chose to have the surgery, it would be premature to place him at MMI.Â  Robinson never had the surgery.Â  
 
Robinson was involved in a second work-related accident on February 11, 2001, when a car he was riding in was rear-ended by another vehicle. Â Robinson was seen by Doctorâ€™s Care on February 14, 2001, and was discharged with the restrictions that he not lift more than ten pounds; not lift anything over his head; perform ground level work only; not engage in repeated bending, stopping, squatting, pushing, jerking, twisting, or bouncing; and not engage in repetitive hand activities for extended periods of time.Â  Robinsonâ€™s discharge instructions further indicated his treatment was to consist of taking pain killers twice a day and applying ice to the affected areas.Â  However, Robinson was not released to work because he had been terminated for poor job performance the previous day, February 13, 2001. Â 
Robinson continued to be seen by Doctorâ€™s Care until he was again referred to Dr. Khoury on April 4, 2001; however, there is no indication that the visit ever occurred.Â  Following Robinsonâ€™s termination, Respondents refused to provide any further treatment. Â However, Robinson did return to Dr. Marzluff on May 9, 2001, complaining of neck and lower back pain.Â Â Â  Dr. Marzluff found Robinson had â€œdiffuse range of motion of the neck in all directionsâ€ but noted â€œ[n]o specific motor or sensory deficit.â€Â  Dr. Marzluff later discharged Robinson, with no permanent impairment rating and at MMI as of July 16, 2001.Â  On the same day, May 9, 2001, Robinson saw chiropractor Dr. Bernie Miller. Â Robinson saw Dr. Miller from May 9, 2001, until December 29, 2001, incurring bills in excess of $6,000.00. Â 
Robinson filed a Form 50 Employeeâ€™s Notice of Claim and Request for Hearing on September 5, 2002, alleging injuries to his head, right shoulder, right upper extremity, neck, back, and chest, arising out of the July 9, 2000 accident.Â  Robinson alleged he was in need of additional medical treatment for his injuries, and he was entitled to TTD payments from â€œJuly 9, 2000 to present.â€Â  On October 4, 2002, Respondent Anderson and its carrier, the Hartford, (collectively Respondents) filed a Form 51 Employerâ€™s Answer to Request for Hearing admitting Robinson suffered a compensable work-related injury, to his neck only, on July 9, 2000.Â  Respondents denied Robinson was in need of additional medical care and denied he was entitled to TTD benefits.
Robinson filed a second Form 50 on September 5, 2002, alleging injuries to his left lower extremity, neck, and back arising out of the February 11, 2001 accident.Â  Robinson alleged he was in need of additional medical treatment for his injuries and that he was entitled to TTD payments from â€œFebruary 22, 2001 to present.â€Â  Respondents filed their Form 51 on October 4, 2002, admitting Robinson suffered a compensable work-related incident on February 11, 2001.Â  Respondents alleged, however, that the injury was only a minor injury to the back and denied Robinson was entitled to any additional medical care or TTD benefits as a result of the injury.Â  
 
On December 5, 2002, Robinson once again returned to Dr. Poletti who obtained another MRI.Â  The MRI taken on January 9, 2003 showed â€œa left sided disc protrusion at the C6-7 level with prominent left neuroforaminal narrowing.â€Â  Dr. Poletti noted â€œ[t]he C6-7 level does show marked disc abnormalityâ€ that was â€œincreased from the previousâ€ visits. Â Dr. Poletti opined Robinson was a candidate for surgery, but it was not something he had to do.Â  Specifically, Dr. Poletti recommended surgery only if Robinson were to reach the point where he cannot live with the problem as it is.Â  Robinson was to follow up with Dr. Poletti as needed.
The accidents were consolidated into one claim that was heard before a single commissioner on March 3, 2003.Â  On July 23, 2003, the single commissioner issued a Decision and Order finding that Robinson was not at MMI for either accident.Â  The single commissioner found that prior to the second accident, Dr. Poletti had mentioned surgery as an option, and Robinson would have had this recommended surgery but for Respondentsâ€™ refusal to authorize the procedure.Â  The single commissioner found that Robinson is in need of further medical treatment for the physical injuries as well as a resulting psychological overlay injury.Â  The single commissioner also found Robinson was entitled to TTD benefits for 22 days following the July 9, 2000 accident and from February 11, 2001 to the present and continuing from the second accident.Â  Finally, the single commissioner found Respondents were responsible for all of Robinsonâ€™s past care and treatment, whether from authorized or unauthorized medical providers. Â 
Both parties appealed the Order of the single commissioner to the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (the commission).Â  Respondents appealed the findings of the single commissioner that Robinson had reached MMI in July of 2001; Robinson wanted the surgery in July of 2001 and Respondents refused to authorize the procedure; a compensable psychological overlay injury existed; Robinson was entitled to the full award of TTD benefits, maintaining that Robinson was only entitled to TTD for 22 days following the first accident; and Respondents were responsible for unauthorized treatment and evaluation before MMI and all treatment and evaluation before MMI.Â  Robinson appealed only the finding allowing Respondents an offset for any unemployment benefits received after February 11, 2001.Â  
 
By Order dated June 29, 2004, the commission affirmed in part and reversed in part the Order of the single commissioner.Â  The commission reversed the finding of fact that Robinson wanted surgery prior to the second accident and that Respondents refused to authorize the procedure.Â  The commission also deleted the finding that this surgery was needed at the time to lessen Robinsonâ€™s disability.Â  The commission also deleted the finding of a compensable claim of psychological overlay injury.Â  The commissionâ€™s order specifically found Robinson reached MMI as of July 16, 2001, based on the medical evidence.Â  The commission found Robinson was neither entitled to, nor in need of, additional medical treatment nor are Respondents responsible for any unauthorized medical expenses or medical expenses incurred after MMI unless specifically authorized.Â  The commission upheld the finding that Respondents were entitled to offset TTD benefits with any contemporaneous unemployment benefits.Â  Finally, the case was remanded for a determination of what, if any, permanent disability Robinson has suffered.
Robinson appealed the Order of the commission to the circuit court contending the commissionâ€™s findings amounted to an error of law and were not based on substantial evidence in the record.Â  Robinson argued the Order of the single commissioner should be reinstated, except for the portion allowing the carrier to offset TTD with unemployment benefits.Â  The circuit court affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded the case to the single commissioner. 
 
Specifically, the circuit court found there was substantial evidence to support a finding that Robinson reached MMI as of July 16, 2001, with regard to any injuries sustained from the two accidents; the commission did not err in finding Respondents are not responsible for all unauthorized treatment before MMI and all treatment after MMI; there was substantial evidence to support a finding that Robinson has not suffered a compensable psychological overlay injury; and the commission erred in allowing Respondents to offset TTD benefits with unemployment benefits.
The circuit court went on to find Robinsonâ€™s representations of employability may provide evidence of an ability to work during the periods of time which he received TTD benefits and, therefore, remanded the case to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission for a finding of whether Robinson can sustain his burden of proving a period of TTD, from the period of February 11, 2001 to July 16, 2001, despite representing himself to the Employment Security Commission as able and willing to work during this period.Â  The circuit court also ordered the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission to make a determination of what amount of permanent disability or loss of use Robinson suffered, if any.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  A reviewing court may reverse or modify a decision of an agency if the findings, inferences, conclusions, or decisions of that agency are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  Bursey v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Under the scope of review established in the APA, this court may not substitute its judgment for that of the commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â Â  Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. S.C. Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 619, 611 S.E.2d 297, 300 (Ct. App. 2005).
â€œThe findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 492, 541 S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001).Â Â Â  Accordingly, a reviewing court may not substitute its judgment for that of the commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact. Â Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 337, 478 S.E.2d 74, 76 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Instead, review of issues of fact is limited to determining whether the findings are supported by substantial evidence in the record. Â Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 289, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610-1 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œOn appeal, this court must affirm an award of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission in which the circuit court concurred if substantial evidence supports the findings.â€Â  Solomon v. W.B. Easton, Inc., 307 S.C. 518, 520, 415 S.E.2d 841, 843 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached to justify its action.â€Â  Howell v. Pacific Columbia Mills, 291 S.C. 469, 471, 354 S.E.2d 384, 385 (1987).

LAW/ANALYSIS

I.  MMI and Additional Medical Care and Treatment 

Robinson contends the commission erred in finding he reached MMI as of July 16, 2001, and in failing to order additional medical care and treatment that would tend to lesson his period of disability.Â Â Â  We disagree.Â  
 
MMI is a term used to indicate that a person has reached such a plateau that in the physicianâ€™s opinion there is no further medical care or treatment which will lessen the degree of impairment. Â Bass v. Kenco Group, 366 S.C. 450, 467, 622 S.E.2d 577, 585 (Ct. App. 2005). Â Â However, the fact that a claimant has reached MMI does not preclude a finding the claimant still may require additional medical care or treatment. Â Dodge v. Bruccoli, Clark, Layman, Inc., 334 S.C. 574, 579-80, 514 S.E.2d 593, 596 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  MMI is a factual determination left to the discretion of the commission.Â  Gadson v. Mikasa Corp, 368 S.C. 214, 224, 628 S.E.2d 262, 268 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Substantial evidence supports the circuit courtâ€™s finding that Robinson reached MMI as to his physical injuries as of July 16, 2001, and is in need of no additional medical treatment.Â  
 
After the January 8, 2001 MRI, Dr. Poletti suggested Robinson have surgery and concluded that, if Robinson chose not to undergo surgery he would be at MMI and his impairment rating would be 10% and if Robinson chose to have the surgery, it would be premature to place him at MMI.Â  Robinson never had the surgery and there is no indication in the record that he wanted the surgery.Â  Dr. Poletti testified he never received communication from Robinson asking for the surgery.Â  While there are letters written by Robinsonâ€™s attorney indicating that Robinson wanted the surgery, these letters were never submitted as evidence and were only shown to the circuit court on May 31, 2005, in correspondence regarding a proposed order.Â  Furthermore, none of the doctorsâ€™ notes indicate Robinson requested the surgery.Â  
 
On July 16, 2001, Dr. Marzluff indicated Robinson had been discharged from his care with no permanent impairment rating, and had reached MMI.Â  And while an injury at the C6-7 is still present, Dr. Poletti testified in his deposition that the C6-7 level injury was not mentioned previously and stated â€œI can say that the disc herniation at C6-7 is most probably not related to the original accident.â€Â  Dr. Poletti also confirmed that the C6-7 herniation had not been apparent in any of the prior MRI scans that he reviewed and that he could not state within a reasonable degree of medical certainty that the surgery he had recommended to Robinson for the C6-7 level was at all related to the original accident.Â  Accordingly, substantial evidence exists to support the circuit courtâ€™s finding that Robinson reached MMI as of July 16, 2001.Â  
 
II.  Psychological Overlay Injury
Robinson contends the circuit court erred in affirming the commission on the issue of his psychological overlay injury.Â  We agree. 
 
The single commissioner found that Robinson was in need of treatment for a psychological overlay injury. Â In its order, the commission deleted the sentence dealing with the psychological overlay injury from the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  However, the commission failed to make specific findings of facts to support its decision on the issue of the psychological overlay injury.Â  â€œThe findings of fact of an administrative body must be sufficiently detailed to enable the reviewing court to determine whether the findings are supported by the evidence and whether the law has been properly applied to those findings.â€Â  Able Communications, Inc. v. South Carolina Public Service Comâ€™n, 290 S.C. 409, 411, 351 S.E.2d 151,152 (1986).Â  Where, as here, an order fails to specifically state the findings of fact relied on in reaching the determination it â€œis impossible for an appellate court to review the order for error, since the reasons underlying the decision are left to speculation.â€ Id. at 411, 351 S.E.2d at 152. Â Accordingly, it was error for the circuit court to affirm the commission on the issue of Robinsonâ€™s psychological overlay injury.
Mental injuries are compensable if they are induced either by physical injury or by unusual or extraordinary conditions of employment. Â Getsinger v. Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp., 335 S.C. 77, 81, 515 S.E.2d 104, 106 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing generally Kennedy v. Williamsburg County, 242 S.C. 477, 131 S.E.2d 512 (1963) and Stokes v. First Natâ€™l Bank, 306 S.C. 46, 50, 410 S.E.2d 248, 250 (1991)).Â  Though, all parties agree that Robinson suffers from psychological problems, Respondents argue these problems stem from a third accident that injured the C6-7 level identified for the first time by Dr. Poletti after the January 9, 2003 MRI.Â  
 
From our reading of the record, it appears that no evidence was presented to show that Robinsonâ€™s psychological problems stem from anything other than his work-related accidents.Â  Robinson saw psychologist Dr. Lewis Waid beginning January 13, 2003.Â  Dr. Waid diagnosed Robinson with depression stemming from the two work-related injuries and subsequent loss of employment.Â  Dr. Waid stated that Robinsonâ€™s pain is directly related to his medical problems. Â Specifically, Dr. Waid stated: â€œIt is my opinion to absolutely a degree of certainty that these â€“ his state of psychological difficulties at this time and pain stem from those two accidents and to a certain extent certainly some stressors that have followed in the context of those accidents.â€Â  While it is true Robinsonâ€™s first noted complaint was not until October 28, 2002, at the office of Dr. Miller, this was still before any mention of a C6-7 level problem.Â  The only evidence presented indicates Robinsonâ€™s psychological injuries stem from his work-related accidents, and there was absolutely no evidence that Robinsonâ€™s psychological problems stem from the alleged third accident.Â  Furthermore, Dr. Waid testified that Robinson is not at MMI concerning his psychological overlay injury.Â  
 
While our reading of the record would result in a different outcome on the issue of the psychological overlay injury than the one reached by the commission, the â€œduty to determine facts is placed solely on the Commission and the court reviewing the decision of the Commission has no authority to determine factual issues but must remand the matter to the Commission for further proceedings.â€Â  Fox v. Newberry County Memorial Hosp., 319 S.C. 278, 280, 461 S.E.2d 392, 394 (1995) (citing Drake v. Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., 241 S.C. 116, 127 S.E.2d 288 (1962)). Â Accordingly, we reverse the circuit court and remand this issue to the commission to make specific findings of fact to support its determination that Robinson did not suffer a compensable psychological overlay injury.Â  If the commission is unable to do so, they should reinstate the single commissionerâ€™s finding as to the psychological overlay injury and, given Dr. Waid testimony that Robinson has not reached MMI concerning his psychological overlay injury, determine the additional medical treatment needed for his psychological injury.Â  
 
III.  Temporary Total Disability
Robinson argues Respondents failed to preserve for appeal the issue of whether Robinson sustained his burden of proving a period of TTD from February 11, 2001 to July 16, 2001, despite representing himself to the Employment Security Commission as able and willing to work during that period.Â  We disagree.
Robinson argues that it was improper for the circuit court to make such a ruling.Â  However, Robinson failed to move to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  At no time prior to this appeal did Robinson argue that it was improper for the circuit court to rule on the issue of TTD. Therefore, this argument is not preserved for our review.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 460, 535 S.E.2d 438, 444-45 (2000).Â  
 
IV.  Use of Improper FactsÂ  

Robinson contends Respondents improperly presented issues and facts outside of the record both through their briefs and in oral arguments.Â  We disagree.Â  
 
After a hearing, the single commissioner left the record open for thirty days to permit Respondents to take the deposition of Dr. Poletti.Â  Specifically, the single commissioner stated: â€œIâ€™m going to leave it open for thirty days with this stipulation, that no testimony from this hearing may be used to craft questions for Dr. Poletti, either direct questions asked at this hearing or indirectly in the way of hypotheticals posed to Dr. Poletti.â€Â  Robinson now claims improper testimony was elicited from Dr Poletti using information gleaned from the initial hearing.Â  However, this issue is not preserved.Â  
 
Initially, while it is true that Robinson objected to some instances of alleged improper questioning, Robinson never raised the issue of the single commissionerâ€™s, commissionâ€™s, or circuit courtâ€™s use of these improper facts until after the hearing before the circuit court.Â  And though the circuit court never ruled on the issue, Robinson failed to raise the issue in a Rule 59(e) motion, as required.Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 460, 535 S.E.2d at 444-45.Â  Furthermore, most of the instances complained of were never objected to during the testimony.Â  See Webb v. CSX Transp., Inc., 364 S.C. 639, 655, 615 S.E.2d 440, 449 (2005) (stating that failure to contemporaneously object precluded CSX from raising issue on appeal).Â  
 
CONCLUSION
Because the circuit court erred in affirming the commission on the issue of Robinsonâ€™s psychological overlay injury, we reverse the circuit court and remand this issue to the commission to make specific findings of fact to support its determination that Robinson did not suffer a compensable psychological overlay injury or to reinstate the single commissionerâ€™s finding as to Robinsonâ€™s psychological overlay injury.Â  All other issues are affirmed.Â  For the reasons stated herein, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is 
 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED. 

STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Robinson missed a total of twenty-two days of work stemming from this accident. Â Â

PER CURIAM:Â  This is a post-conviction relief (PCR) action in which the Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from the denial of his application for PCR.Â  The PCR judge granted Petitioner, pursuant to White v. THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Alexanderâ€™s Land Company, L.L.C.; Alexanderâ€™s Restaurant Company, Inc.; Franz Auer; John Peterson, Jr., and Bruce O. Rossmeyer, Plaintiffs,
				Of whom Alexanderâ€™s Land Company, L.L.C. and Alexanderâ€™s Restaurant Company, Inc. are the Appellants,
				v.
				M&M&K Corporation; IFBIFB Corporation, and Roger Keyes are Defendants
				Of whom M&M&K Corporation and IFBIFB Corporation are the Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-364
Heard December 5, 2006 â€“ Filed August 29, 2007

REVERSED AND REMANDED 



	
		
			
				C. Mitchell Brown, of Columbia and Richard A. Farrier, Jr., Walter T. Cox and Andrea St. Armand, all of Charleston, for Appellants.
				Stephen E. Carter, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Alexanderâ€™s Restaurant Company, Inc. (Purchaser) appeals the trial judgeâ€™s decision denying its request for specific performance of an option to purchase real estate.Â  We reverse and remand.

FACTS

In 1996, M&M&K Corporation (Seller) operated a restaurant called Alexanderâ€™s (the Restaurant) on Hilton Head Island.Â  IFBIFB Corporation (Owner) owned the premises upon which the Restaurant was located (the Premises).Â  Rodger Keyes is the sole shareholder of both corporations.Â  At the time, Seller leased the Premises from Owner.Â 
 
On November 25, 1996, Purchaser entered into a complex business deal with Seller and Owner, for the sale of both the Restaurant and the Premises that would extend over a three to five year period.Â  The framework for the deal and the partiesâ€™ obligations were provided in an Asset Acquisition Agreement (the Agreement) to which three additional agreements related to the transaction were attached as exhibits: a Personal Property Lease (the Lease); a Sublease (the Sublease); and, a Restated Commercial Lease (the Restated Lease).[1]  
The Agreement provided for the purchase of the Restaurant business for a total of $1,300,000.00.Â  Under the Agreement, Purchaser was to take possession of the Restaurant, the Date of Possession, on December 2, 1996[2] and was to purchase and close on the Restaurant, the Closing Date, on December 1, 1999.Â  However, the Agreement gave Purchaser the right to extend the Closing Date for two, one year periods.Â  If Purchaser intended to extend the Closing Date, it had to give Seller written notice ninety days in advance of the Closing Date, September 1 of each year.Â  
 
During this period, while Purchaser maintained possession of the Restaurant but not yet purchased the business, Purchaser rented the Restaurant from Seller, as provided under the Lease.Â  The Lease contained identical dates as the Agreement, such that if Purchaser extended the Closing Date for the purchase of the business, the Lease would likewise be extended.Â  
 
Since the Restaurant was situated on leased premises, Purchaser also had to obtain Sellerâ€™s right to lease the Premises from Owner.Â  The parties executed the Sublease which likewise contained identical dates as the Agreement and the Lease, such that the Purchaser had to extend the Sublease if it extended the Closing Date of the purchase of the business.Â  When Purchaser closed on the purchase of the business, the Restated Lease would take place of the Sublease.[3] Â 
Paragraph 22.16 of the Sublease contained an option (the Option) allowing Purchaser to purchase the Premises.Â  The Option likewise contemplated notice and closing dates similar to the Agreement, Lease, and Restated Lease.Â  The first time Purchaser could exercise the Option was, â€œnot earlier than ninety (90) days prior to the commencement of the first renewal term,â€ i.e. September 1, 1999. Â The last time Purchaser could exercise the Option was, â€œnot later than ninety days prior to the end of the second renewal term,â€ i.e. September 1, 2001.Â  The Option also contained a condition precedent requiring Purchaser to have â€œconsummated the purchase of [Sellerâ€™s] business,â€ before it could exercise the Option.[4]Â  
 
From December 16, 1996 to August 26, 1999, the parties operated according to the terms of the Agreement, Lease, and Sublease.Â  On August 26, 1999, providing Seller ninety days notice, Purchaser extended the Closing Date on the purchase of the business, and thereby extended the Lease, Sublease and Option contained in the Sublease, for one-year.Â  In 2000, Purchaser did not provide ninety days written notice to extend the Closing Date, the Lease, Sublease or Option.Â  In November 2000, the parties began negotiating a modification of the Agreement to allow Purchaser to extend the Closing Date through December 1, 2001.Â  
 
The parties did not reach a compromise and Purchaser did not close on December 1, 2000, as required by the Agreement.Â  Accordingly, Seller sent notice of default on December 4, 2000, triggering Purchaserâ€™s thirty-day cure period under the Agreement.Â  On December 13, Seller waived the default, and the parties reinstated the Agreement, Lease, and Sublease. Â Seller additionally extended all of the agreementsâ€™ respective terms to provide a Closing Date of December 1, 2001.Â  
 
In summer 2001, the parties again began negotiating a modification, and resulting extension, of the Closing Date on the purchase of the business, Lease, Sublease, and Option.Â  On August 9, Terry Finger, the attorney for Purchaser, wrote Cary Griffin, the attorney for Seller and Owner, indicating Purchaser wished to exercise the Option to purchase the Premises but wanted to extend the Closing Date on the purchase of the business for an additional four years.Â  Griffin replied by letter dated August 14, indicating the Option to purchase the Premises was dependant on the purchase of the business such that Purchaser could not exercise the Option in 2001 without also purchasing the business in 2001.Â  Griffin also reminded Finger of the upcoming notice deadlines, as contemplated in the Agreement.Â  Griffin did suggest that perhaps at a later date and after a discussion with his clients that both purchases could be extended.Â  
 

	On August 27, Finger faxed a memo to Griffin:
	
		This confirms our recent phone conversations.Â  [Peterson] and his partners will exercise option on property and we would like to follow up on [Peterson and Keyesâ€™] recent conversation about extending remainder for 3-5 yrs.
	

On September 5, Griffin wrote Finger, informing him the Option had expired on September 1, 2001, â€œno notice has been received as to the exercise of the Option to Purchase. . . . Hence, the Option to Purchase, on its face, is extinguished.â€Â  Griffin later testified that at the time of the September 5 letter, he did not know Fingerâ€™s August 27 memo had been received by his office.Â Â Â  
 
Griffin and Finger attempted to resolve the problem.Â  On November 15, 2001, Finger tendered the earnest money deposit required in the Option.Â  Griffin returned the check, reiterating his position the Option had expired.Â  By mutual agreement, the parties closed on the Restaurant on December 7, 2001.Â  As a result, Purchaser owned the Restaurant and leased the Premises pursuant to the Restated Lease.Â  However, Purchaser reserved its right to litigate the issue of whether the Option expired.Â  
 
Purchaser filed a complaint against Owner, Seller, and Keyes (collectively Defendants).Â  Purchaser asked for specific performance of the Option.Â  In addition, Purchaser sought a declaratory judgment defining the rights of the parties pursuant to the Agreement, Lease, and Sublease.Â  Furthermore, Purchaser alleged unfair and deceptive trade practices, sought damages for breach of contract, and asked for quantum meruit recovery of the improvements it made to the Premises.Â  
 
Defendants answered, denying liability.Â  The trial judge held a hearing, at which the parties presented evidence.Â  Defendants argued the Option expired because (1) Purchaser failed to satisfy the condition precedent of purchasing the Restaurant before attempting to exercise the Option and (2) Purchaser failed to tender the earnest money deposit before the Option deadline of September 1, 2001.Â  Purchaser asked for the relief requested in its complaint.Â  Moreover, Purchaser contended Defendants should be equitably estopped from arguing the Option expired and Defendants did not comply with the default provision in the Agreement.Â  
 
The trial judge found in favor of Defendants, holding Purchaser failed to satisfy the condition precedent to exercise the Option and Purchaser did not properly exercise the Option because it did not tender the earnest money deposit.Â  Purchaser moved for reconsideration, and the trial judge issued an amended order correcting minor factual inaccuracies.Â  Subsequently, the trial judge issued a separate order awarding attorneysâ€™ fees to Defendants.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.Â  Hardy v. Aiken, 369 S.C. 160, 164-65, 631 S.E.2d 539, 541 (2006).Â  An appellate court must look to the â€œmain purposeâ€ of a suit to determine its characterization.Â  Williams v. Wilson, 349 S.C. 336, 340, 563 S.E.2d 320, 322 (2002); Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 544, 590 S.E.2d 338, 345 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Thus, characterization of an action as equitable or legal depends on the plaintiffâ€™s â€œmain purposeâ€ in bringing the action.Â  Ins. Finâ€™l Servs., Inc. v. S.C. Ins. Co., 271 S.C. 289, 293, 247 S.E.2d 315, 318 (1978).Â  Whether the action is one at law or in equity is determined by the nature of the pleadings and the character of the relief sought.Â  In re Estate of Holden, 343 S.C. 267, 278, 539 S.E.2d 703, 709 (2000).
In this case, Purchaser, as plaintiff, clearly requested equitable relief in the nature of specific performance and equitable estoppel.[5]Â  See Campbell v. Carr, 361 S.C. 258, 262-63, 603 S.E.2d 625, 627 (Ct. App. 2004) (recognizing an action for specific performance is one in equity); McDaniel v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 325 S.C. 405, 409, 481 S.E.2d 155, 157 (Ct. App. 1996) (holding estoppel is equitable in nature).Â  Purchaserâ€™s primary cause of action seeks specific performance, while it secondarily asks for damages from breach of contract.Â  Moreover, Purchaserâ€™s request for relief seeks a declaratory judgment and specific performance based on the rights as declared.Â  Furthermore, at trial, Purchaser characterized the action as one for specific performance of the Option.Â  
 
On appeal of an action in equity, tried by the judge alone, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its views of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Grosshuesch v. Cramer, 367 S.C. 1, 4, 623 S.E.2d 833, 834 (2005).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require the appellate court to disregard the findings of the trial judge.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Exercise of the Option
 Purchaser contends the trial judge erred in finding Purchaser had not properly exercised the Option because it did not: 1) tender the earnest money or 2) satisfy the condition precedent that it purchase the business prior to the exercise of the Option.Â  Additionally, Purchaser argues if it were required to perform the condition precedent of closing on the business prior to exercising the Option, the court should have found that such failure to perform was subject to the default and right to cure provisions in the Sublease.Â  
 
A.  Earnest Money and Condition Precedent
Option contracts are strictly construed in favor of the optioner and against the optionee.Â  Cotter v. James L. Tapp Co., 267 S.C. 647, 653, 230 S.E.2d 715, 717 (1976).Â  â€œIf the option requires performance in a certain manner, time is of the essence and exact compliance with the terms of the option are required.â€Â  Id. at 653, 230 S.E.2d at 717-18.Â  â€œIf the option contract specifically makes the tender of the purchase price a condition precedent to the optionâ€™s exercise, then the plain language of the contract controls and actual tender is required.â€Â  Ingram v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 S.C. 98, 110-11, 531 S.E.2d 287, 293 (2000).Â  However, in situations when the option contract does not specifically make tender a condition precedent, a court should â€œconsider the context in which the contract was made and attempt to effectuate the intent of the contracting parties.â€Â  Id. at 111, 531 S.E.2d at 293-94.Â  
 
The Defendants contend and the trial judge held that Purchaserâ€™s written notice of its intent to exercise the Option on August 27, 2001, absent the tender of earnest money, did not comply with the exact terms of the Option as required by South Carolina law.Â  Thus, a review of South Carolina law on the exercise of options aids the court in determining this case. 
 
In Cotter v. James L.
